abase.description: lower in rank or status; humiliate
abase.sentence: The mentor did not abase the student for mistakes, but gently guided her.

abate.sentence: As the storm abated, the sea became calm and tranquil.

abdicate.description: give up a position, right, or power
abdicate.sentence: The king decided to abdicate the throne in favor of his son.

aberrant.sentence: The scientist observed an aberrant result that deviated from the norm.

acumen.description: the ability to make good judgments and quick decisions
acumen.sentence: Her business acumen helped the startup rapidly become profitable.

adroit.description: skillful and adept under pressing conditions
adroit.sentence: The debater was adroit at countering complex arguments.

adulation.sentence: Despite the crowd's adulation, the artist remained humble.

adversity.sentence: He learned to remain positive even in the face of adversity.

affluent.description: having a great deal of money; wealthy
affluent.sentence: They lived in an affluent neighborhood with large mansions.

alacrity.sentence: She accepted the invitation with alacrity, eager to attend.

alleviate.description: make suffering, deficiency, or a problem less severe
alleviate.sentence: The medicine helped alleviate the pain after surgery.

amalgamate.description: combine or unite to form one structure
amalgamate.sentence: The two companies decided to amalgamate to increase market share.

ambiguous.description: open to more than one interpretation; unclear
ambiguous.sentence: The politician's ambiguous statement left his position unclear.

anachronism.description: something out of its proper time period
anachronism.sentence: Using a smartphone in a medieval setting is an obvious anachronism.

anomaly.description: something that deviates from what is standard or expected
anomaly.sentence: The engineer noted an anomaly in the test data that required investigation.

apathy.description: lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern
apathy.sentence: Voter apathy led to a surprisingly low turnout at the polls.

arcane.description: understood by few; mysterious or secret
arcane.sentence: The professor's lecture on quantum physics was filled with arcane concepts.

audacious.description: showing a willingness to take bold risks
audacious.sentence: The explorer's audacious plan included crossing the uncharted jungle.

austere.description: severe or strict in manner; without adornment
austere.sentence: The monks lived in an austere monastery with few comforts.

avarice.description: extreme greed for wealth or material gain
avarice.sentence: His avarice drove him to hoard gold and ignore the needs of others.

belligerent.sentence: Her belligerent attitude made her unpopular among her coworkers.

benevolence.description: the quality of being kind and generous
benevolence.sentence: Her benevolence was evident when she donated her entire bonus to charity.

benevolent.sentence: Her benevolent nature made everyone feel welcome in the community.

berate.sentence: The coach did not hesitate to berate the players for their lack of effort.

bestow.sentence: The award committee decided to bestow the prize on the young scientist.

bewilder.sentence: The complex puzzle began to bewilder even the most experienced players.

blandish.description: coax with kind words or flattery
blandish.sentence: He tried to blandish his boss with compliments to earn a promotion.

boisterous.sentence: The children were boisterous as they played in the park.

cacophony.description: a harsh, discordant mixture of sounds
cacophony.sentence: A cacophony of car horns filled the city street during the rush hour.

capricious.description: given to sudden behavior changes; impulsive
capricious.sentence: The weather is so capricious in spring that you must dress in layers.

catharsis.description: the process of releasing strong emotions, providing relief
catharsis.sentence: Writing in a journal provides a catharsis for his stress.

cavalier.description: showing a lack of proper concern; offhand
cavalier.sentence: She had a cavalier disregard for the rules, doing as she pleased.

chaos.sentence: After the power outage, the office descended into chaos.

chauvinist.description: believing in the superiority of one's own group, often nationalistic
chauvinist.sentence: His chauvinist attitude alienated many people in the meeting.

cinematic.sentence: The director created a cinematic masterpiece that captivated audiences worldwide.

circumspect.description: wary and unwilling to take risks
circumspect.sentence: She was circumspect about investing, researching each option carefully.

clandestine.sentence: They held a clandestine meeting to plan the surprise party.

coerce.description: persuade to do something by using force or threats
coerce.sentence: He tried to coerce his friend into breaking the law, but was refused.

cogent.sentence: Her cogent argument convinced the panel to approve the project.

colloquial.description: used in ordinary or familiar conversation
colloquial.sentence: The novel's dialogue felt authentic because of its colloquial tone.

concur.description: be of the same opinion; agree
concur.sentence: Both experts concur that this is the most efficient solution.

connive.description: secretly allow or conspire to do something immoral or illegal
connive.sentence: They were shocked to discover the neighbors connived to steal their idea.

consensus.sentence: After much debate, a consensus was reached on the proposal.

construe.description: interpret or understand (a word or action)
construe.sentence: It is difficult to construe his silence on the matter.

conundrum.description: a confusing and difficult problem or question
conundrum.sentence: The riddle posed quite a conundrum that stumped everyone.

conviction.sentence: Her conviction that justice will prevail inspired everyone around her.

copious.sentence: The report was filled with copious data and detailed charts.

cumulative.description: increasing or increased by successive additions
cumulative.sentence: The cumulative effect of the donations was astounding.

cursory.description: hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed
cursory.sentence: He gave the document a cursory glance but signed it without reading.

dearth.description: a scarcity or lack of something
dearth.sentence: The region suffered a dearth of clean water during the drought.

debacle.description: a sudden and ignominious failure; a fiasco
debacle.sentence: The product launch turned into a debacle when the software crashed.

debilitate.sentence: The illness served to debilitate him, leaving him bedridden.

decorum.description: behavior in keeping with good taste and propriety
decorum.sentence: The students were expected to act with decorum during the formal dinner.

deference.sentence: Out of deference to tradition, they observed the annual ceremonies.

deleterious.sentence: Smoking can have deleterious effects on your health.

denounce.description: publicly declare to be wrong or evil
denounce.sentence: They decided to denounce the corrupt official at the press conference.

deride.sentence: Bullies often deride those who are different.

declaim.description: utter or deliver words in a rhetorical or impassioned way
declaim.sentence: The politician began to declaim against the injustices he witnessed.

decrepit.description: worn out or ruined because of age or neglect
decrepit.sentence: They lived in a decrepit old mansion on the hill.

diffident.description: modest or shy because of a lack of self-confidence
diffident.sentence: The normally diffident student surprised everyone with her eloquent speech.

diminutive.sentence: Despite his diminutive stature, he had an imposing presence.

disdain.description: the feeling that something is unworthy of one's consideration
disdain.sentence: She looked at the messy desk with disdain.

disseminate.sentence: The internet helps disseminate information faster than ever.

dissent.description: hold or express opinions at variance with the majority
dissent.sentence: To dissent publicly could have consequences.

distortion.description: the action of giving a misleading account or impression
distortion.sentence: He refused to listen to any distortion of the facts.

dissident.description: a person who opposes official policy
dissident.sentence: The dissident criticized the government's new regulations.

dogmatic.description: inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true
dogmatic.sentence: He was dogmatic about his views and refused to listen.

dour.sentence: His dour expression told me that he had not slept well.

dubious.description: hesitating or doubting; not to be relied upon
dubious.sentence: He was dubious about the truth of the rumors.

durable.description: able to withstand wear, pressure, or damage
durable.sentence: She bought a durable pair of boots for the harsh winter.

eccentric.sentence: The eccentric artist painted bright murals on every wall of her house.

elated.sentence: She was elated when she learned she got the scholarship.

electrify.sentence: The guitarist managed to electrify the audience with his solo.

elicit.description: evoke or draw out (a reaction or response)
elicit.sentence: The comedian's jokes would often elicit laughter from the crowd.

embellish.description: make (something) more attractive by adding decorative details
embellish.sentence: She decided to embellish her speech with a few anecdotes.

empirical.sentence: The theory needed empirical evidence before it could be accepted.

enigmatic.sentence: His smile was enigmatic, leaving everyone guessing his true feelings.

ephemeral.description: lasting for a very short time
ephemeral.sentence: The beauty of a sunset is ephemeral.

epiphany.sentence: It was an epiphany when he finally understood the solution.

equanimity.sentence: Despite the chaos, he maintained his equanimity.

eradicate.description: destroy completely; put an end to
eradicate.sentence: Efforts were made to eradicate the invasive plant species.

ethical.sentence: She faced an ethical dilemma about telling the truth.

estranged.description: no longer close or affectionate to someone
estranged.sentence: The estranged siblings met only once a year.

eulogy.sentence: He delivered a touching eulogy at his grandmother's funeral.

fervent.description: having or displaying a passionate intensity
fervent.sentence: She was a fervent advocate for animal rights.

flagitious.sentence: The serial thief's flagitious acts were well known to the police.

flagrant.sentence: The referee ignored the flagrant foul.

futile.description: incapable of producing any useful result; pointless
futile.sentence: Protesting seemed futile in front of the unyielding judge.

gaudy.sentence: The decorations were so gaudy that they hurt his eyes.

genial.sentence: The genial host greeted each guest with a warm smile.

gullible.sentence: He was so gullible that any tall tale would convince him.

gratuitous.sentence: The movie had a gratuitous violent scene that many found unnecessary.

haughty.sentence: She gave a haughty look to the man who had insulted her.

harried.sentence: She seemed harried after juggling work and family.

hypocritical.description: behaving in a way that suggests high standards not followed
hypocritical.sentence: Criticizing others for faults he had himself was clearly hypocritical.

humane.sentence: The humane treatment of the animals impressed the visitors.

imbue.description: inspire or permeate with a feeling
imbue.sentence: The teacher tried to imbue students with a love of reading.

imbalance.description: lack of proportion or relation between corresponding things
imbalance.sentence: An imbalance in the ecosystem can lead to severe consequences.

implement.description: put into effect according to a plan or procedure
implement.sentence: The school will implement the new policies next semester.

impromptu.description: done without being planned in advance
impromptu.sentence: She gave an impromptu speech when the main speaker was delayed.

incisive.description: clear and sharp in expression or thought
incisive.sentence: His incisive question cut right to the heart of the issue.

indelible.description: making marks that cannot be erased; memorable
indelible.sentence: The experience left an indelible mark on her mind.

inherent.sentence: There is an inherent difficulty in this problem.

innocuous.sentence: The comment was innocuous and caused no offense.

inundate.description: overwhelm with a large amount of something
inundate.sentence: The office was inundated with calls after the announcement.

irascible.sentence: The old man was known to be irascible after midnight.

ire.sentence: His unjust treatment earned him the ire of the villagers.

irreverent.description: showing lack of respect for things taken seriously
irreverent.sentence: His irreverent comments about the ceremony shocked the audience.

irate.sentence: He wrote an irate letter to the editor about the recent policy change.

joviality.sentence: The joviality of the party was infectious.

judicious.description: showing or done with good judgment or sense
judicious.sentence: Her judicious advice helped me solve the difficult problem.

kinetic.description: relating to or resulting from motion
kinetic.sentence: The exhibit showcased kinetic sculptures that moved with the wind.

kindle.sentence: The teacher hoped to kindle a love of science in her students.

keen.description: having or showing eagerness or enthusiasm
keen.sentence: She had a keen interest in learning foreign languages.

layman.sentence: He explained the scientific concept in layman's terms.

lexicon.description: vocabulary of a person or language
lexicon.sentence: She had a rich lexicon of culinary terms.

lucid.sentence: He gave a lucid explanation of the complex theory.

magnanimous.description: generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival
magnanimous.sentence: She was magnanimous in victory, praising her opponent's effort.

magnate.description: a wealthy and influential person in business
magnate.sentence: The real estate magnate built an empire in just a decade.

malevolent.description: having a wish to do evil to others
malevolent.sentence: His malevolent glare sent shivers down their spines.

malleable.sentence: Gold is a malleable metal that can be shaped easily.

marred.sentence: The once beautiful painting was marred by years of neglect.

meager.sentence: They survived on a meager diet during the winter.

mediocre.description: of only average quality; not very good
mediocre.sentence: The movie received only mediocre reviews from critics.

metamorphosis.sentence: The caterpillar's metamorphosis into a butterfly amazed the children.

modernize.description: adapt to modern needs or habits
modernize.sentence: The museum decided to modernize its exhibits with interactive displays.

mollify.description: make less angry or severe; soothe
mollify.sentence: She tried to mollify the irate customer with a free coupon.

magnitude.sentence: The magnitude of the earthquake was measured at 7.2.

manifest.sentence: The joy on her face was manifest when she won.

mundane.sentence: He performed the mundane task of filing papers.

naive.description: showing lack of experience or judgment
naive.sentence: He was naive to believe everything he heard.

negligent.description: failing to take proper care in doing something
negligent.sentence: The negligent driver did not notice the pedestrian.

notorious.sentence: The outlaw was notorious across the frontier.

novelty.description: the quality of being new or original
novelty.sentence: The novelty of virtual reality technology intrigued him.

oblivious.description: unaware of or paying no attention to someone or something
oblivious.sentence: She was oblivious to the fact that everyone was staring at her.

obsolete.description: out of date; no longer used
obsolete.sentence: Typewriters became obsolete after computers gained popularity.

ominous.description: giving the impression that something bad is about to happen
ominous.sentence: The dark clouds looked ominous above the city.

onerous.sentence: Filling out the paperwork was an onerous task.

outrageous.sentence: It was outrageous how much he demanded for the simple job.

outright.sentence: She was the outright winner of the competition.

paradox.description: a statement that contradicts itself but may be true
paradox.sentence: It is a paradox that standing is more tiring than walking.

parsimonious.sentence: The parsimonious manager refused to spend on new equipment.

paucity.sentence: The paucity of evidence made the case difficult to solve.

pedantic.sentence: His pedantic remarks annoyed the rest of the class.

peripheral.description: on the edge; not of central importance
peripheral.sentence: The incident was peripheral to the main issue.

pernicious.sentence: The pernicious weed spread throughout the farmland.

perpetuate.sentence: Spreading rumors will only perpetuate misunderstandings.

phantom.description: something that seems real but is not; ghost
phantom.sentence: He chased phantom fears about the future.

philanthropy.description: the desire to promote the welfare of others
philanthropy.sentence: She engaged in philanthropy by building schools in impoverished areas.

phenomenon.sentence: Auroras are a natural phenomenon seen in polar regions.

pious.sentence: Her pious devotion led her to volunteer at the church.

placid.sentence: The lake was placid in the early morning light.

plausible.sentence: Her explanation was plausible, so they believed her story.

plethora.sentence: There was a plethora of ideas during the brainstorming session.

plight.sentence: They were rescued from their plight by kind neighbors.

plagiarize.description: copy and pass off someone else's work as one's own
plagiarize.sentence: Students are warned not to plagiarize assignments.

precocious.description: developing abilities at an earlier age than usual
precocious.sentence: The precocious child could read by age three.

predicament.sentence: Losing his job put him in a financial predicament.

procrastinate.sentence: He would procrastinate on homework until the last minute.

proliferate.sentence: Social media platforms continue to proliferate around the world.

prosaic.sentence: The report was filled with prosaic details that bored the readers.

prosaically.description: in a straightforward or matter-of-fact manner
prosaically.sentence: He prosaically listed the items he needed for the project.

protagonist.description: the main character in a story
protagonist.sentence: The protagonist faced a moral dilemma at the story's climax.

prudent.sentence: Saving for emergencies is a prudent financial habit.

pugnacious.description: eager or quick to argue or fight
pugnacious.sentence: The pugnacious boxer won match after match.

quarantine.sentence: After returning from travel, they had to quarantine for two weeks.

quell.sentence: The police were called to quell the disturbance.

querulous.sentence: His querulous tone irritated everyone in the meeting.

quibble.sentence: Let's not quibble over minor details right now.

quintessence.description: the most perfect example of something
quintessence.sentence: He was the quintessence of kindness.

rambunctious.sentence: The puppies were so rambunctious, they knocked over a vase.

ramification.sentence: They considered every ramification of the proposed law.

rapacious.description: greedy or grasping, often in a negative sense
rapacious.sentence: The rapacious landlord raised the rent without warning.

rationalize.sentence: She tried to rationalize her decision with statistics.

rebut.sentence: He attempted to rebut the accusations in his defense.

recant.description: withdraw a statement or belief formally
recant.sentence: Under pressure, the witness decided to recant her testimony.

redundancy.sentence: The essay contained redundancies that needed to be removed.

rejuvenate.description: make someone feel younger or fresher
rejuvenate.sentence: A vacation by the ocean can really rejuvenate the mind.

relinquish.sentence: He had to relinquish control of the company.

renegade.description: person who deserts a cause and goes independent
renegade.sentence: The spy became a renegade after defecting to the enemy.

reticent.description: not revealing one's thoughts readily; reserved
reticent.sentence: She was reticent to speak at the meeting.

reverie.description: a daydream; state of being lost in thought
reverie.sentence: Lost in reverie, he almost missed the announcement.

resilient.sentence: Children are often resilient and adapt to changes easily.

reminisce.sentence: They would often reminisce about their college days.

rescind.sentence: They decided to rescind the offer when new information came to light.

sagacious.sentence: The sagacious leader guided the nation through crisis.

sanctuary.description: a place of refuge or safety
sanctuary.sentence: The wounded deer found sanctuary in the forest.

sardonic.sentence: His sardonic smile annoyed his critics.

scrupulous.sentence: She was scrupulous about following every rule.

sensory.description: relating to sensation or the senses
sensory.sentence: The spicy soup created a strong sensory experience.

serene.sentence: They sat by the lake enjoying the serene afternoon.

solicit.description: ask for or try to obtain (something)
solicit.sentence: He would often solicit feedback from his mentors.

sophisticated.description: developed to a high degree of complexity; refined
sophisticated.sentence: The new computer system has a sophisticated interface.

spontaneous.description: performed or occurring without premeditation; impulsive
spontaneous.sentence: Her spontaneous decision led to a memorable adventure.

succinct.sentence: His succinct reply answered all our questions.

succumb.description: give in to pressure or temptation
succumb.sentence: She would not succumb to pressure from her friends.

superfluous.sentence: He cut out all superfluous details from the report.

synoptic.description: giving a general summary or overview
synoptic.sentence: She provided a synoptic summary of the year's events.

surreal.sentence: Walking into the room filled with balloons felt surreal.

tacit.sentence: They had a tacit agreement not to discuss the topic.

tactile.description: relating to the sense of touch
tactile.sentence: The fabric had a pleasant tactile quality.

talisman.description: an object believed to bring good luck
talisman.sentence: The old ring was considered a family talisman.

tantrum.sentence: The toddler's tantrum was heard down the hall.

teeming.sentence: The marketplace was teeming with shoppers.

tangible.description: perceptible by touch; clear and real
tangible.sentence: They needed tangible evidence before proceeding.

taunt.description: to jeer at or mock someone
taunt.sentence: The older kids would often taunt the younger ones.

thrifty.description: using money and resources carefully; not wasteful
thrifty.sentence: Being thrifty helped them save for their future.

transient.description: temporary; lasting only a short time
transient.sentence: The beauty of the sunset was transient but unforgettable.

travesty.description: a distorted or absurd representation of something
travesty.sentence: The trial was a travesty of justice, with no real evidence presented.

treacherous.sentence: The mountain road was narrow and treacherous.

tribulation.description: a cause of great trouble or suffering
tribulation.sentence: She remained strong through every tribulation.

truculent.description: eager to argue or fight; aggressively defiant
truculent.sentence: His truculent attitude got him into trouble.

turbulent.sentence: The country went through a turbulent period after the war.

tyranny.description: cruel and oppressive government or rule
tyranny.sentence: They rebelled against the tyranny of the regime.

ubiquitous.sentence: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.

undermine.sentence: Negative comments can undermine a person's confidence.

untenable.description: not able to be defended or justified

utopia.description: an imagined perfect place or state
utopia.sentence: He dreamed of a utopia where everyone was equal.

usurp.description: take a position of power illegally or by force
usurp.sentence: The general tried to usurp the throne.

vacuous.description: having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence
vacuous.sentence: The conversation was vacuous, focused only on trivial matters.

venerate.sentence: They venerate the ancient traditions of their culture.

venerable.description: accorded a great deal of respect, especially because of age or wisdom
venerable.sentence: The venerable professor had taught at the university for over fifty years.

vengeance.description: punishment inflicted in return for an injury or wrong
vengeance.sentence: He swore vengeance for the betrayal.

verdict.description: a decision on a disputed issue in a civil or criminal case
verdict.sentence: The jury returned a guilty verdict after deliberation.

vexation.description: the state of being annoyed or worried
vexation.sentence: Losing the keys caused great vexation.

vilify.description: speak or write about in an abusively disparaging manner
vilify.sentence: It was wrong to vilify the whistleblower for doing his job.

virtue.sentence: Patience is a virtue worth cultivating.

virtuoso.description: a person highly skilled in music or art
virtuoso.sentence: She was a piano virtuoso at just twelve years old.

vociferous.sentence: The protesters were vociferous in their demands.

volatile.description: liable to change rapidly and unpredictably
volatile.sentence: The political climate was volatile at the time.

voracious.description: having a very eager approach to an activity or devouring large amounts of food
voracious.sentence: He had a voracious appetite for learning new languages.

vulnerable.description: exposed to the possibility of being attacked or harmed
vulnerable.sentence: Young seedlings are vulnerable to frost.

waive.sentence: They decided to waive the fees for the charity.

wanderlust.sentence: His wanderlust took him across five continents.

warrant.sentence: The evidence did not warrant such a severe punishment.

wary.description: feeling or showing caution about possible dangers
wary.sentence: She was wary of the stranger's intentions.

wistful.description: having or showing a feeling of vague or regretful longing
wistful.sentence: She gave a wistful glance at her childhood home.

xenophobia.description: intense or irrational dislike or fear of foreigners
xenophobia.sentence: A surge in xenophobia has troubled the community.

xylophone.description: a musical instrument with wooden bars of different lengths
xylophone.sentence: The musician played a tune on the xylophone.

yearn.description: have an intense feeling of longing
yearn.sentence: He would yearn for his family while on tour.

yoke.description: to join together or harness animals
yoke.sentence: Farmers used an oxen yoke to plow the field.

zeal.description: great energy or enthusiasm in pursuit of a cause
zeal.sentence: Her zeal for baking filled the kitchen with fresh bread.

zenith.sentence: He reached the zenith of his career at age forty.

zephyr.sentence: A zephyr blew through the open window on a summer day.
